Description: Colorado Interstate Gas Company, operator of the Natural Buttes Compressor Station located on the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation near Vernal, Utah, agreed to pay more than $1 million and install environmental controls at its facility as part of a consent decree that resolved violations of the Clean Air Act.

Description: El Paso Corporationagreed to pay $7.7 million to settle allegations that it indirectly paid nearly $5.5 million in illegal surcharges to Iraq in connection with its purchases of crude oil from third parties under the United Nations Oil for Food Program.

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced a Clean Air Act settlement with El Paso Midstream Group, LLC (El Paso) resolving violations at the Blue Bell Gas Plant near Roosevelt in Duchesne County, Utah.The settlement requires the company to pay $20,000 in civil penalties and up to $235,000 toward funding and maintaining two regulatory air monitors in the Uintah Basin.

Description: Kinder Morgan Port Manatee Terminal LLC, a Delaware company doing business in Manatee County, Florida, has agreed to plead guilty to four separate violations of the Clean Air Act. Description: El Paso Corp. agreed to pay more than $70 million to settle allegations of conspiring to reduce the transmission capacity in the El Paso Pipeline in an attempt to elevate natural gas prices in Arizona and increase profits.

State negotiators in California finalized a settlement with El Paso Corporation that would provide $1.45 billion in relief to electricity and gas ratepayers. The deal resolved an investigation of the company's role in the California energy crisis of 2000-2001. Approximately $92 million of the settlement went to the states of Oregon, Washington and Nevada.

El Paso Natural Gas agreed to pay $225,000 in settlement of allegations it failed to comply with state and federal air quality regulations governing the removal and replacement of asbestos-coated pipeline.
El Paso Natural Gas agreed to pay $115,000 in settlement of allegations it operated as an illegal treatment, storage and disposal facility and as an illegal transporter of hazardous waste.
Tennessee Gas Pipeline LLC agreed to pay $640,000 in settlement of a lawsuit concerning eminent domain acquisition of conservation land to extend a gas pipeline.

The Long Beach City Attorney announced that El Paso Corporation agreed to pay $17 million to settle litigation alleging that the company manipulated the energy market during the 2000-2001 energy crisis. This ended up being part of a $1.45 billion settlement the company later reached with the state government and other localities; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-el-paso-corporation-1
Info Source: L.B. settles suit against gas firm, Long Beach Press-Telegram, March 26, 2003 (via Nexis).

Description: Kinder Morgan agreed to pay $20 million in settlement of allegations that petroleum releases from the Mission Valley Terminal had contaminated groundwater at the Qualcomm Stadium site.

Shell, Mobil, Texaco and Kinder Morgan agreed to pay a total of $700,000 in settlement of allegations that two sites the companies used in San Diego for fuel storage or pipelines had contaminated soil and groundwater. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here was assume the total was divided equally among them.

Description: SFPP, a subsidiary of Kinder Morgan, agreed to pay $2.5 million in fines, restoration and costs in settlement of criminal charges it failed to immediately report a discharge of 63,000 gallons of gasoline from a pipeline into a state waterway.
